Package com.barryholroyd.evermore Description

Top-level package for Evermore -- primarily initialization and configuration.

The following lists some of the key items driving the architecture/design of Evermore.

  • Mapping
    • Evermore is very map-centric. Because very little of interest can be done without the map in place, most processing can't proceed until the Google Map is present.
    • Mapitems are wrappers around GoogleMap markers. GoogleMap creates markers to represent locations on the map (typically by a pin icon). Unfortunately, these markers are ephemeral -- they go away when there is a device configuration change and they take their ids with them. A new set has to be generated every time there is a device configuration change (e.g., when the device is rotated). The MapItem class was created as a long-lived wrapper around a marker -- MapItems (along with their ids) survive device rotations. MapItems contain additional relevant information for the marker, such as the BitMapDescriptor used to create the marker's icon.
  • Persistence
    • SharedPreferences are used to store most persistent data (such as user settings). See SettingsManager and Settings.
    • A SQLite database is used to cache Contacts data pulled from the user's address book. See com.barryholroyd.evermore.contacts.
    • Simple field data which needs to survive configuration changes (e.g., caused by device rotations) is stored in the StorageBank. Initially, I implemented the StorageBank using Fragments with setRetainInstance(true), but I found that this introduced unnecessary complexity and reverted to the use of simple static variables.
    • The only large/complex data which needs to survive configuration changes is the set of MapItems created by the user. For a discussion of managing that data set, please see com.barryholroyd.evermore.mapitems.
  • Miscellaneous
    • There are three primary screens: Main, Map and List. Since they are all driven by the same set of data, a single Activity is used to display the screens and fragments are used to load each of them on demand.
    • A very object-oriented approach it taken for handling user input. The two main screens are broken up into several panels, the intent being that each panel can then be treated as an object. For example, the leds for all of the search buttons in the left panel can be turned off by calling PanelLeft.clearLeds.
      • PanelsAppbar
      • PanelsLeft
      • PanelsTop
      • PanelsBottom
